sections.title: Jonathan Renews Alliances With Foreign Nations
Letter from the King of Sparta to Onias
Jonathan Prepares for War Against Demetrius

verses.text: When Jonathan saw that his time was favorable, he chose men and sent them to Rome to renew and confirm the friendship with them.
verses.comment: Jonathan acts diplomatically, seeking alliances helpful for Israel. The mention of Rome foreshadows the spread of God's plan through Gentile nations (see Acts 18:1-3, the presence of Jewish leaders in Rome).
verses.sectionHeader: Jonathan Renews Alliances With Foreign Nations

verses.text: He also sent letters to the Spartans and to other places for the same purpose.
verses.comment: Jonathan's outreach to multiple nations shows a wisdom of maintaining peace with neighbors, reminiscent of David's envoys (see 1 Chronicles 19:6).

verses.text: So they journeyed to Rome and entered the senate and said, 'Jonathan the high priest and the nation of the Jews send greetings.'
verses.comment: Here the high priest serves as the nation's representative, emphasizing spiritual leadership. This anticipates Christ's role as high priest and mediator (Hebrews 4:14, see also Ezra 4:11 for greetings from leaders).

verses.text: They presented to them letters about the renewal of friendship and alliance, as it was before.
verses.comment: Alliance-building reinforces the theme of covenant. Compare friendship covenants in the life of David (1 Samuel 18:3).

verses.text: They gave these letters also to the Spartans and to other places.
verses.comment: The distribution of letters to multiple nations reflects Israel's mission to be a light to the peoples (see 1 Kings 9:16, expanding relationships).

verses.text: Jonathan wrote also to the Spartans: 'Jonathan the high priest, the elders, the priests, and the rest of the Jewish people to the Spartans, their brothers: Greetings.'
verses.comment: The greeting includes the high priest, elders, priests, and people. This structure resembles the leadership and organization later seen in the Church (see Nehemiah 2:2 for similar greetings by Jewish leaders).

verses.text: Long ago, a letter was sent to the high priest Onias from Areus, king of the Spartans, stating that you are our brothers, as the copy attached shows.
verses.comment: The claim of brotherhood with the Spartans points to ancient connections and the idea of universal brotherhood under God, hinting at the later union of all believers.

verses.text: Jonathan sent again to renew the friendship.
verses.comment: Renewing friendship echoes wisdom literature’s emphasis on faithful relationships (see Proverbs 12:14).

verses.text: Therefore, though we have no need of these things, since we have as encouragement the holy books that are in our hands,
verses.comment: The focus on the holy books reflects the primacy of Sacred Scripture as comfort and guide, connecting Psalm 119:105, 'Your word is a lamp to my feet.'

verses.text: we have undertaken to send to renew our family ties and friendship with you, so that we may not become estranged from you, for considerable time has passed since you sent your letter to us.
verses.comment: Jonathan desires unity, echoing Joseph's reunion with his brothers (Genesis 45:24), hinting at spiritual kinship among God's people.

verses.text: We therefore remember you constantly on every occasion, both at our festivals and on other appropriate days, at the sacrifices that we offer and in our prayers, as it is right and proper to remember brothers.
verses.comment: Remembering others during sacrifices highlights the liturgical life and the remembrance of the faithful during worship (Leviticus 23:37).

verses.text: We are glad about your glory.
verses.comment: Sharing joy in others’ blessings builds unity (2 Corinthians 1:14).

verses.text: But as for ourselves, many trials and many wars have encircled us; the kings around us have waged war against us.
verses.comment: Recalling conflict reminds us of Israel's constant struggle, a theme present in King David's time (2 Samuel 5:3).

verses.text: We were unwilling to annoy you and our other allies and friends with these wars,
verses.comment: Out of respect and humility, Jonathan refrains from burdening allied nations amid trials (1 Samuel 20:17).

verses.text: for we have the help that comes from Heaven for our aid, and so we were delivered from our enemies, and our enemies were humbled.
verses.comment: Victory leads to a renewal of friendships, restoring peace, as seen after deliverance in Judges 8:22.

verses.text: We therefore have chosen Numenius son of Antiochus and Antipater son of Jason, and have sent them to Rome to renew our former friendship and alliance with them.
verses.comment: Envoys act as mediators, anticipating the later role of apostles as ambassadors for Christ (Esther 3:7, messengers for the king).

verses.text: We have commanded them to go also to you and greet you and deliver to you this letter from us concerning the renewal of our family ties.
verses.comment: The sending of envoys with letters resembles apostolic visits and epistles in the New Testament (2 Timothy 4:21).

verses.text: Please reply to us about this.
verses.comment: Invitation to reply encourages relational communication, as modeled by early Christian communities (1 Corinthians 16:19).

verses.text: This is the copy of the letter sent to Onias:
verses.comment: Preserving copies of important letters foreshadows the tradition of safeguarding scriptural and apostolic writings (Nehemiah 7:5).
verses.sectionHeader: Letter from the King of Sparta to Onias

verses.text: King Arius of the Spartans, to the high priest Onias, greetings.
verses.comment: Greetings from a foreign king to the Jewish high priest shows respect for spiritual authority (Nehemiah 9:1).

verses.text: It has been found in writing concerning the Spartans and the Jews that they are brothers and are of the family of Abraham.
verses.comment: This claim of descent from Abraham connects Gentile nations to the promise, foreshadowing inclusion of all in God's family (Genesis 22:17-18).

verses.text: And now that we have learned this, please write us concerning your welfare;
verses.comment: Deep kinship is expressed in sharing possessions, echoing Old Testament inheritance and unity (Numbers 34:9).

verses.text: 'We have instructed our representatives to speak with you about this.'
verses.comment: The use of representatives foreshadows the later sending of apostles on behalf of Christ (Esther 8:10).

verses.text: Jonathan heard that the commanders of Demetrius had returned to attack him with a larger force than before.
verses.comment: Returning enemies mirrors Saul's pursuit of David, a persistent challenge to the faithful (1 Samuel 22:8).
verses.sectionHeader: Jonathan Prepares for War Against Demetrius

verses.text: He marched from Jerusalem to meet them in the region of Hamath, for he did not allow them to invade his own territory.
verses.comment: Defending the land is a duty for God’s people, echoing Solomon’s defense of borders (1 Kings 8:65).

verses.text: He sent spies into their camp, who returned and reported, 'They are planning a night attack on you.'
verses.comment: Spies often shape the outcome of battles in Scripture (Joshua 7:4). Strategic wisdom is valued.

verses.text: So as the sun set, Jonathan's army prepared for battle and stood watch all night, ready to fight.
verses.comment: Night watches are a motif of vigilance and preparation (Judges 7:19).

verses.text: But the enemy learned that Jonathan and his men were ready for battle, so they became afraid and withdrew, lighting fires in their camp.
verses.comment: God often sows fear in the hearts of enemies (see Judges 15:4 for divine intervention in battle).

verses.text: Jonathan and his men saw the fires, but did not know what had happened until morning.
verses.comment: Waiting until morning evokes deliverance through night hours (Exodus 14:22).

verses.text: Then Jonathan pursued them but could not overtake them, as they had crossed the river Eleutherus.
verses.comment: The enemies escape across a river, reminiscent of Israel’s adversaries evading capture (Joshua 2:10).

verses.text: So Jonathan turned aside against the Arabs called Zabadeans and attacked them, taking their spoils.
verses.comment: Turning aside for battle sometimes leads to unexpected victory (Judges 8:24, Gideon’s spoils).

verses.text: Then Jonathan returned to Damascus, traveling through the whole region.
verses.comment: Passing through Damascus is notable: compare Paul’s journey (Acts 9:3), where God’s plan unfolds among the nations.

verses.text: Simon meanwhile advanced as far as Ashkalon and its neighboring towns. Then he turned to Joppa and took it over, for he had heard that the people there planned to hand its stronghold over to Demetrius.
verses.comment: Simon secures strategic cities, as Joshua did during Israel’s conquest (Joshua 19:6).

verses.text: He stationed a force to guard it.
verses.comment: Guarding cities reflects the wisdom of protecting holy places and the faithful (1 Chronicles 18:13).

verses.text: Jonathan returned and gathered the elders of the people. Together they decided to rebuild the walls and fortify Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Jointly rebuilding walls recalls Nehemiah's call to restore Jerusalem, signaling communal leadership and protection (Nehemiah 2:17).

verses.text: He ordered the construction of a high wall between the citadel and the city, to separate it and ensure its defense.
verses.comment: Separating and strengthening the city walls is a sign of wise governance, as Nehemiah showed (Nehemiah 4:13).

verses.text: The troops of the foreign garrison had withdrawn to the citadel, but they were unable to go into or out of the city.
verses.comment: Restricting enemy movement demonstrates God’s favor in protecting Jerusalem (Ezra 6:22).

verses.text: Simon supplied Jerusalem with all necessary provisions.
verses.comment: Providing for the city points to God's provision of manna—physical needs tied to spiritual leadership (Exodus 16:2).

verses.text: Then Trypho planned to become king of Asia, put on a crown, and attack Antiochus to kill him.
verses.comment: A rival rising for the throne is a recurring biblical theme (2 Samuel 2:8).

verses.text: But he feared that Jonathan might prevent this, so he sought to capture and kill him.
verses.comment: Trypho's plotting mirrors Saul's schemes against David (see 1 Samuel 23:23)—faithful leaders often face such threats.

verses.text: Then Trypho moved his army to attack, but Jonathan took all his forces and prepared for battle against him at the water near Hamath. However, Trypho did not allow his men to cross over.
verses.comment: This passage presents the strategic maneuvering between Trypho and Jonathan. The location near Hamath is significant, reminding readers of key battles in Israel's history and the importance of military leadership entrusted to God’s chosen people.

verses.text: Trypho sent a detachment of horsemen against Jonathan, saying, 'We come to make peace with you. Hand over your weapons and troops, for we will make no war against you.'
verses.comment: Trypho’s duplicity is exposed here, echoing other scriptural themes of false promises (cf. 1 Samuel 18:20-21), reminding us to discern spirits and intentions behind apparent gestures of peace.

verses.text: So Jonathan trusted them and did as they said, sending away his troops to the cities, while he remained with only a few men.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s trust is reminiscent of other faithful yet tragic figures, showing the burden of leadership and the need for discernment in troubled times.

verses.text: Then Trypho captured Jonathan and all who were with him. All that remained.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s capture underscores the vulnerability of even the righteous when faced with deceit. The text calls to mind betrayals and captivities in Israel’s history, such as that of Samson (Judges 16:21).

verses.text: Trypho sent cavalry and infantry to Galilee and the Great Plain to destroy all of Jonathan’s followers.
verses.comment: Aggressive pursuit of Jonathan’s supporters mirrors many occasions in Scripture when the faithful are persecuted, foreshadowing trials endured by God’s people (Matthew 24:9).

verses.text: But the followers, when they heard that Jonathan had been captured and killed, encouraged one another and marched out united, ready for battle.
verses.comment: The unity and encouragement among Jonathan’s followers underlines the enduring strength of Israel’s community—not unlike the unity required of Christ’s Church (Acts 4:32). Spiritual unity in adversity is a recurring theme.

verses.text: Those who had been sent by Trypho saw that Jonathan’s supporters were determined to fight for their lives, and so they turned back.
verses.comment: God often grants courage to His people in the face of adversity, turning the enemy away. Here, the steadfastness of Jonathan’s followers causes the attackers to retreat, reminding us of God’s providential protection.

verses.text: Trypho gathered all his cavalry and returned to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Trypho’s withdrawal reflects the defeat of hostile agendas by the resolve of the faithful—a pattern seen throughout Israel’s history and foreshadowing spiritual victories in the New Covenant.

verses.text: He destroyed and burned the gates and sections of the surrounding wall of Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Destruction of the city walls brings to mind earlier devastations of Jerusalem. Walls represent spiritual security, which in Christian interpretation is fulfilled in the one enduring foundation of the Church (Psalm 127:1).

verses.text: Then he withdrew, departing to return to Ptolemais.
verses.comment: Trypho’s withdrawal to Ptolemais leaves Jerusalem exposed—a theme paralleling periods of vulnerability in biblical history, yet always followed by restoration as God’s mercy abides.

verses.text: He kept Jonathan in custody with him.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s captivity is reminiscent of the imprisonment of other faithful leaders in Scripture. It signifies the trials of righteous leadership and the anticipation of their vindication (Matthew 27:17).

verses.text: Simon was deeply grieved when he heard what had happened to Jonathan. He gathered his army in preparation to face Trypho.
verses.comment: Simon's sorrow for his brother echoes biblical expressions of mourning for the faithful, yet also the readiness to continue the spiritual battle. The passage reflects the ongoing leadership and the call to perseverance in the face of trial.

verses.text: When the enemies of Israel heard that Simon had taken Jonathan’s place as leader, they rose up to challenge him and all the land around was against him.
verses.comment: Simon’s succession and immediate challenge reveals the continual struggle between God's people and their adversaries. Leadership succession is a central theme in Scripture and points to Christ’s appointment of successors to shepherd His people, ensuring continuity and unity.
